body:
I've had a a quick look at some of the failing tests for OpenBSD, and some -- like this one -- look like the calls to `removeAll` are failing because the dirs are not empty. Whatever it is, it's obviously racy too.

I don't know *anything* about go or the Syncthing codebase, but if one of the devs could tell me how to do some kind of print debugging I can look deeper. I've tried inserting `fmt.print` and `log.Printf` calls in `removeAll` but see nothing printed in the output. Am I missing something?

I'm wondering if perhaps `Glob` behaves differently on OpenBSD and the set of files that needs to be removed is incomplete... Not sure though.
l.Infoln should be available, or simple println() which should be available. RemoveAll should do a recursive remove.

It may also be a good idea to check the returned errors of all those functions and fail if they are non-nil. Then it is at least clear whether that's a problem or not. Currently we mostly just ignore these.

Alright, well `println` works.

The test creates a parent dir, then a child under the parent, removes the parent recursively and tries to scan the child.

Removing the parent sometimes fails. This is the call to ` testFs.RemoveAll(parent)` in the test, which ends up at `func (f *BasicFilesystem) RemoveAll(name string) error {` in `basicfs.go`. This is what is failing.

The removal fails because the directory is not empty, which I suppose means that something else is creating a file in the parent at the same time as the parent is being recursively removed?

Are these directories created in a non-blocking fashion? I assume `fc.addFile` is what is creating them? Maybe we need to wait for the child to be created before continuing?

Here's the relevant bit of the test
```
        parent := "foo"
        child := filepath.Join(parent, "bar")
        testFs := fs.NewFilesystem(fs.FilesystemTypeBasic, tmpDir)

        received := make(chan []protocol.FileInfo)
        fc.addFile(parent, 0777, protocol.FileInfoTypeDirectory, nil)
        fc.addFile(child, 0777, protocol.FileInfoTypeDirectory, nil)
        fc.mut.Lock()
        fc.indexFn = func(folder string, fs []protocol.FileInfo) {
                received <- fs
                return
        }
        fc.mut.Unlock()
        fc.sendIndexUpdate()

        // Get back index from initial setup
        select {
        case fs := <-received:
                if len(fs) != 2 {
                        t.Fatalf("Sent index with %d files, should be 2", len(fs))
                }
        case <-time.After(time.Second):
                t.Fatalf("timed out")
        }

        // Delete parent dir
        if err := testFs.RemoveAll(parent); err != nil {
                println("TESTFS REMOVEALL FAIL")
                t.Fatal(err)
        }
```

`fc.addFile` is just "syncthetic", meaning it fakes a connection to a non-existing device - no disk io involved. Neither is the operation racy: The infos are received, the two dirs created and only then are the infos sent, which then unblocks in line 579. Meaning the removal that fails happens after pull operations. Of course there may be delay in the disk io on a lower level, but then I'd expect the removal to be delayed too.
Would it help if I granted one of you guys SSH access to an OpenBSD machine?

http://ix.io/1qta

FreeBSD has similar issues when running tests for github.com/syncthing/syncthing/lib/fs

Note: The FreeBSD port does not appear to run tests when building. (Did not see anything in the Makefile for net/syncthing)

This might confirm that the issue is *BSD related, not just OpenBSD. Hope this helps.

Edit: I'm seeing other tests failing as well in a non-deterministic way. 

Same lib/fs, and now --- FAIL: TestAPIServiceRequests (7.72s)

They are not, however, the same failure as above. Have not seen that one yet.
So getting access to a bsd machine could help, but I am living out of a suitcase with no access to a proper pc for potentially one more month, so I can't help in the short term.

I'd be happy to fling up a VM for a few days, but we should try to co-ordinate on timing, as it'd be a paid VM.

Unless anyone else has a machine they don't mind giving an account out on, or which they can create a VM on.

Cheers

@AudriusButkevicius Are you back home? Just wondering if we could take a look at this soon. If so, I can get you a BSD machine up and  running.

Thanks
Not yet sadly... Moving in Sunday, but I suspect I won't have access to my PC till Christmas.

Sorry to be super-annoying and persistent, but my offer still stands to set you up a VM to squash those OpenBSD/syncthing test failures.

Just say the word and I'll sort it out.

Thanks
Hey, I am finally back online. Send me the details over email, I'll have a look once I've done other non-fun adult stuff.
This seems to pass on the VM I was given.

Hi,

I'm able to reproduce this one on my laptop. It seems sensitive to the machine we are running on. We know from above that it's racy, so I guess different CPU speeds etc can expose or hide the failure. I remember not being able to repro on my desktop.

I suppose this is the same inotify issue @AudriusButkevicius ? If so, can we skip this test also?

```
--- FAIL: TestParentDeletion (0.02s)
    requests_test.go:606: remove /tmp/_request-182950755/foo: directory not empty
FAIL
FAIL    github.com/syncthing/syncthing/lib/model        58.983s
```

^ on master.

Thanks

That test does not involve the filesystem watcher, so it should be unrelated. Should because I think the filesystem watcher is not deactivated and might thus influence the test scenario, potentially in ways to make it fail spuriously (haven't actually looked at the code, just remember explicit full scans being used before checking test conditions).
Should we re-open this then?
Only if you have a way to reproduce this and debug this. I don't want to have tickets lying around which are impossible to fix.
OK, I'm going to run this test in a loop on the VM and see if I can get it to fail.

Actually this looks like it's a golang problem. The error comes from

```golang
	if err := testFs.RemoveAll(parent); err != nil {
		t.Fatal(err)
	}
```

which in turn calls `os.RemoveAll` which should remove the directory and its content - to my understanding that should never fail with `directory not empty`.

Hrm, fwiw, I'm using go-1.11.4.

Here's more information about failures. There's actually three failing tests here, but let's look at `TestParentDeletion` first:
https://gist.github.com/vext01/8ab7c6c134ccda6f9a2480ddd10e8ba3

BTW, what's the command to run that test in isolation. The command I used earlier in the issue doesn't seem to work any more:
```
$ STRACE=model go test -v -run TestParentDeletion 
can't load package: package github.com/syncthing/syncthing: build constraints exclude all Go files in /home/edd/go/src/github.com/syncthing/syncthing
```

You must be in the directory of the package that the test belongs to, here `lib/model` - you cannot run specific tests from the repository root.

Embarrassingly I didn't read the issue and thus haven't seen that you already discovered that `os.RemovAll` is the source. To check for simultaneous creation in the to be removed directory, you should add `fs` to the STTRACE env var. Also I guess this does not happen every time you run the script?

Here's a paste showing two consecutive runs of the test where the first fails and the second succeeds:

https://gist.github.com/vext01/c1f815f8fe0f78a2ae17aa8920d62cca

For future reference, the command was:
```
for i in {0..50}; do env STTRACE="model fs" go test -v -run TestParentDeletion; done 2>&1 | tee LOG
```

Can you apply this change and try whether you can reproduce it again please.

```diff
diff --git a/lib/model/requests_test.go b/lib/model/requests_test.go
index c6d9e3d1f..e179bb8ae 100644
--- a/lib/model/requests_test.go
+++ b/lib/model/requests_test.go
@@ -601,6 +601,8 @@ func TestParentDeletion(t *testing.T) {
                t.Fatalf("timed out")
        }
 
+       m.ScanFolders()
+
        // Delete parent dir
        if err := testFs.RemoveAll(parent); err != nil {
                t.Fatal(err)
```

The scan should just make sure that any pull operations (which creates `foo/bar`) is done before the parent is removed.
